Subject: Re: [neat] Evolving Coordinated Quadruped Gaits with the HyperNEAT Generative Encoding

Jeff,  My reply to Ken's questions might have clarified some of your
quest=
ions as well.  Please see below for more specific responses.

At Tue, 24 Fe=
b 2009 14:03:11 -0500,
Jeff Clune wrote:
> 
> > Interesting work!
> 
> Than=
ks Vinod! 
> 
> > I was also curious to see how HyperNEAT would
> > perform=
 on this domain.  The videos of quadruped and hexapod gaits I
> > evolved, =
and the paper I wrote with Prof. Risto Miikkulainen for last
> > year's GEC=
CO are available here:
> > 
> >      http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?modula=
rne
> 
> I read your paper when you posted it last year. I think it is very=

> interesting work. In particular, I think it is cool that you can produce=
 all
> of these different types of gaits.

Thanks!  The different gaits are=
 a consequence of the coupled cell
system formalism, which predicts those g=
aits.

> I do not get that kind of variety with
> HyperNEAT, but I think th=
at is because I am only using one fitness function
> (speed) and the two ga=
its I get reliably may simply be faster than the other
> types of gaits.

I=
f you set up the substrate as I suggested so that it represents a
coupled c=
ell system, then HyperNEAT may also be able to produce those
other gaits.

=
> Why do you think you do not see a collapse down to a single
> fastest gai=
t type in your work? Is it because you bias them so strongly to
> one type =
of gait (in each setup) that they cannot override that bias and
> choose a =
faster gait? 

My fitness function is also speed (distance travelled in one=
 minute of
simulated time), and it is the same for all cases.  I observed p=
ronk,
bound, and trot in different runs using the same experimental setup
b=
ut different random seeds.  I think it is because these three gaits
have ro=
ughly the same speed for the robot morphology and experimental
conditions I=
 used.  However, I observed pace only when I changed other
experimental par=
ameters, including the maximum joint angular velocity
that the controller c=
an produce (you can see that the legs move slower
for the pace gait in the =
video).

> If so, that is a cool and interesting results, so I am
> merely =
asking out of curiosity and not as a criticism. It is good to be able
> to =
get these systems to produce the types of gait we want in addition to
> sim=
ply producing fast gaits.

I agree, that would be useful.  The types of gai=
ts that are possible
are determined by the coupled cell system.  For exampl=
e, the walk gait
of a quadruped in which legs move a quarter period out of =
phase is not
possible in the coupled cell system I used in the GECCO paper.=
  Thus,
we can restrict the set of possible gaits by selecting a suitable
c=
oupled cell system.  However, I don't think it is always possible to
find a=
 coupled cell system that can produce only one given gait.

> 
> I wonder i=
f I selected for certain slower speeds, or if I selected for
> energy effic=
iency, if I would get different gaits that are more commonly
> seen in natu=
re. It would be a cool experiment to try.

Yes, that would be an interestin=
g experiment to run.

> 
> Out of curiosity, how would you label these two =
gaits?
> 
> I think of this as pronk:
> 
> http://devolab.msu.edu/sites/dev=
olab.msu.edu/files/HyperNEAT_medianFitness_1
> .mpeg

Yes, that looks like =
a pronk.

> 
> and this as gallop:
> 
> http://devolab.msu.edu/sites/devola=
b.msu.edu/files/HyperNEAT_bestIndividual_
> 1.mpeg

I disagree for this one=
.  In the above gait, it looks like three legs
are synchronous and the four=
th leg is of opposite phase.  In contrast,
in gallop, none of the legs are =
synchronous and they hit the ground at
different times.  See the following =
wikipedia page for horse gaits

  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_gait

=
or the following paper (pages 434--435) for phases of legs in
different gai=
ts

  S. V. Shastri. A biologically consistent model of legged locomotion
 =
 gaits. Biol. Cyber., 76(6):429--440, 1997.

> 
> I think it looks like a g=
allop because to me it looks like this:
> 
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F=
ile:Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif
> 
> > With only minor adjustments to=
 your setup, you can convert your
> > substrate configuration to represent =
non-linear oscillators.  In fact,
> > you would get a configuration similar=
 to my modular controllers by
> > restricting the network inputs to just th=
e joint angles and producing
> > angular velocities instead of angles as ou=
tputs.
> 
> Those changes alone would make them non-linear oscillators? But=
 the only
> change you mention is reducing the number of inputs. How would =
taking out
> some of the inputs (the touch sensor, the pitch, roll, yaw and=
 sine) change
> my system to possess non-linear oscillators? Or do you mean=
 that there are
> other 'minor adjustments' that need to be made? If so, wh=
at would
> they be?

I also mentioned changing the outputs from desired ang=
les to desired
angular velocities, and that is actually the crucial change =
necessary
to represent a coupled cell system.  Removing the touch, pitch, r=
oll,
yaw, and sine inputs is not crucial.  They are also not necessary in
p=
rinciple, if you make the above change to the interpretation of
outputs.  I=
 suggested removing them only to make the system simpler
and therefore perh=
aps easier to evolve.  See my previous reply to Ken
for a description of ho=
w this change would allow the substrate to
represent a coupled cell system,=
 and therefore generate gaits.

> 
> How would you describe my system? Do I=
 have linear-oscillators? Or
> linear-non-oscillators? Please forgive me if=
 these are na=EFve questions, but
> I am very interested in learning the pr=
oper terminology for this
> field.

Your system is non-linear because of th=
e sigmoid squashing function in
the network.  However, I don't think the sy=
stem is an oscillator in
the sense that it generates oscillations because y=
ou are driving the
system with an external oscillatory signal.

> 
> > Hype=
rNEAT would then
> > have to evolve the modularity that I specified by hand=
.  I think that
> > would be an interesting experiment to run, and if succe=
ssful would
> > eliminate the need to specify the sine input.
> 
> I think =
I am missing something. Reducing the number of inputs would not
> suddenly =
obviate the need for the sine wave.

Let me know if my previous explanation=
s have not yet clarified this
point.

> 
> Nevertheless, I do think it woul=
d be an interesting experiment to see
> whether HyperNEAT can produce the g=
aits you obtained, but I think whether
> that occurs is related to the fitn=
ess function issue I raised above.

I agree that the fitness function can i=
nfluence the gaits produced.
Even in the coupled cell system formulation, i=
t would be interesting
to design fitness functions that select some gaits o=
ver others from
the set of gaits allowed by the dynamics of the system.

> =

> > BTW, did you find that
> > the other inputs (i.e. pitch, yaw, roll, an=
d touch) were necessary to
> > evolve good gaits in your experiments?
> 
> =
For the setup in the paper, such information increased performance (althoug=
h
> I wouldn't call the extra information necessary, as the experiments wit=
hout
> such information still evolved coordinated gaits, just slower ones).=

> 
> I did experiments with and without PRY (pitch, roll and yaw) and the
=
> performance was better with PRY inputs. I also ran experiments with and
>=
 without the touch information and found that the touch information helped.=

> Oddly, and to my disappointment, I found that these results depended on
=
> other aspects of the system. For example, when I used a different period =
for
> the sine wave, and the gaits were thus different (e.g. much faster an=
d more
> frantic), it was no longer the case that the PRY and touch informa=
tion
> helped. As such, the system does seem to be somewhat chaotic and the=
refore
> general statements such as "PRY inputs help" are unjustified.  I d=
on't fully
> understand why that is the case, although I have some ideas.
>=
 

That's interesting to know, but I don't have an explanation for the
resu=
lts you observed either.

Vinod

> 
> Thanks for your questions and comment=
s.
> Jeff
